original_topology.topology_structure: Hierarchical topology with a core layer (Cisco Catalyst 9500), distribution layer (Aruba CX 6300, Juniper EX4300), and access layer (Cisco CISO switch).  A Juniper SRX firewall is placed between the core and distribution layers on the left side. A Cisco router connects to the internet.

modified_topology.topology_structure: Hierarchical topology with a core layer (Cisco Catalyst 9500), distribution layer (Aruba CX 6300, Juniper EX4300), and access layer (Cisco CISO switch).  A Juniper SRX firewall is placed between the core and distribution layers on the left side. A Cisco router connects to the internet.

recommended_device.justification: The Aruba CX 8300 offers comparable performance and scalability to the Cisco Catalyst 9500, while providing a unified platform for networking and security.  Its advanced features like VXLAN support and multi-tenancy enhance flexibility and efficiency. The 8300 is chosen over smaller CX models due to the core's role and the likely future growth.
recommended_device.cost_benefit: High initial investment, but potential for long-term cost savings through reduced operational complexity and increased efficiency.

compatibility_analysis.existing_connections: Requires compatible cabling and configuration changes.
compatibility_analysis.protocol_support: Supports standard protocols like STP, RSTP, MSTP, and OSPF.

recommended_device.justification: No replacement needed; already an Aruba CX device.

specifications.throughput: High, potentially exceeding the Juniper SRX depending on the configuration

recommended_device.justification: The Aruba CX 8300's integrated security features eliminate the need for a separate firewall, simplifying the network and reducing costs.  This consolidates security and switching functions onto a single platform.
recommended_device.cost_benefit: Higher initial cost than replacing only the firewall, but lower operational costs and increased efficiency.

compatibility_analysis.existing_connections: Requires compatible cabling and configuration changes.
potential_issues: Migration of firewall rules and policies.

recommended_device.justification: The Aruba CX 6200 offers comparable functionality to the Juniper EX4300, maintaining the hierarchical structure and feature parity.  It's chosen for cost effectiveness while keeping a similar feature set.
recommended_device.cost_benefit: Medium to high initial investment but potential for long-term cost savings.

compatibility_analysis.existing_connections: Requires compatible cabling and configuration changes.
compatibility_analysis.protocol_support: Supports standard protocols like STP, RSTP, MSTP, and OSPF.

recommended_device.justification: The Aruba CX 6100 is a cost-effective solution for the access layer, offering sufficient performance and PoE+ for the connected devices.

compatibility_analysis.existing_connections: Requires compatible cabling and configuration changes.
compatibility_analysis.protocol_support: Supports standard protocols like STP, RSTP, and MSTP.

topology_modifications.structural_changes: The core will be replaced with an Aruba CX 8300, which integrates the security capabilities of the Juniper SRX.  Distribution and Access layers will be replaced with Aruba CX 6200 and CX 6100 respectively.
topology_modifications.performance_impact: Improved performance and scalability are expected due to the advanced features of the Aruba CX platform.
topology_modifications.security_enhancements: Enhanced security through the integrated security features of the Aruba CX 8300.

phases.description: Phased rollout of the new devices.
Final cutover and decommissioning of old devices.

implementation_plan.testing_strategy: Rigorous testing will be conducted in a staging environment before deployment to production.

cost_analysis.hardware_costs: The cost will vary depending on specific model choices and quantity.  A detailed quote is needed from an Aruba vendor.
cost_analysis.implementation_costs: Include professional services for design, implementation, and migration.
cost_analysis.operational_savings: Potential savings through reduced operational complexity and consolidated management.
cost_analysis.total_project_cost: A detailed cost estimate will require further information on specific model choices, quantities, and professional services.

topology_explanation: Network topology analyzed and recommendations generated
context_sources:
Response

Introduction

This response provides a detailed analysis for replacing Cisco and Juniper devices with Aruba CX devices, ensuring feature parity. The solution includes a network topology, feature comparison, configuration examples, and a cost analysis.

Feature Comparison and Device Selection

Assumptions

  • Cisco Devices: Cisco Nexus 9000 Series (e.g., Nexus 9332C)
  • Juniper Devices: Juniper QFX5200 Series
  • Aruba Devices: Aruba CX 8400 and 6300 Series

Key Features Comparison

Feature Cisco Nexus 9000 Juniper QFX5200 Aruba CX 8400/6300
Port Density High (48x 1/10G) High (48x 1/10G) High (48x 1/10G)
Switching Capacity 3.6 Tbps 3.8 Tbps 3.8 Tbps
EVPN/VXLAN Support Yes Yes Yes
Redundancy VSS/ISSU MC-LAG/ISSU IRF/ISSU
Security Features ACI, micro-segmentation Junos Space, micro-segmentation Aruba Fabric, micro-segmentation
OS Features NX-OS Junos OS ArubaOS

Gaps and Justifications

  • Aruba CX 8400/6300:
    • Gap: Slightly lower port density compared to Cisco Nexus 9000.
    • Justification: Aruba's ease of management and integration with Aruba Fabric compensate for this gap.

Network Topology

Current Topology

Cisco Nexus 9000 (Core) | |-- Juniper QFX5200 (Distribution) | |-- Access Layer Switches

Proposed Topology with Aruba CX

Aruba CX 8400 (Core) | |-- Aruba CX 6300 (Distribution) | |-- Access Layer Switches

Configuration Examples

VLAN Configuration on Aruba CX

cli configure terminal vlan 10 name Management untagged 1/1/1 exit vlan 20 name Data untagged 1/1/2 exit

Interconnect Configuration (IRF)

cli configure terminal stacking enable stack-member 1 mac-address <MAC-Address> stack-member 2 mac-address <MAC-Address> exit

Redundancy Configuration (ISSU)

cli configure terminal boot system primary flash primary_image.bin boot system secondary flash secondary_image.bin issu enable exit

Cost Analysis

Cost Comparison

Device Cisco List Price Juniper List Price Aruba List Price
Core Switch $45,000 $42,000 $40,000
Distribution Switch $30,000 $28,000 $26,000
Total $75,000 $70,000 $66,000

Cost Justification

  • Total Cost Savings: $9,000 (12% less than Cisco)
  • Value Added: Aruba's integrated management and Aruba Fabric enhance network manageability and security.

Justification and Conclusion

Feature Parity and Enhancements

  • Aruba CX 8400/6300 offer comparable or superior features to Cisco and Juniper devices, with advanced security and ease of management.
  • Redundancy and HA are maintained through IRF and ISSU, ensuring high availability.

Economic Advantage

  • Cost-Effective: Aruba devices provide significant cost savings without compromising on features.
  • Ease of Integration: Simplifies network management and reduces operational costs.

Conclusion

Replacing Cisco and Juniper devices with Aruba CX 8400 and 6300 Series offers a cost-effective, feature-rich solution with enhanced manageability and security. The proposed topology and configuration ensure seamless integration and maintain redundancy and HA.
